Hi all, Liz reckoned this'd perhaps be one for Janos?:

We launched a Lords consultation minisite last week at www.london2012.com/lordsconsultation (or www.london2012.com/lords/home.html) .  I just got asked by the department here who it's for to find out about page views etc so far.  Liz and I just had a look through google analytics just now and it's being pretty strange.  Only the page 'lords-at-games-time' seems to be coming up, and page view figures are very low.  We'd expect them to be pretty low to be honest, these sites aren't usually particularly visited, but it's odd that pages (including the minisite homepage) aren't being brought up at all in analytics, even though they do contain the tracking code.  

Would someone mind having a look at the code in the consultation site pages for us and seeing if they can see any reason why it wouldn't be working properly?  Ta in advance
Janos, would you mind taking a look at this?
Just to confirm, the previous comment says it should (zendesk didn't screw up the code). Finn, please reopen if you want me to go over the ~20 files.

Thanks Janos, I'll do the replacing, no worries. Cheers very much for
the input

 

________________________________

I think that this is because you chose a page, rather than an pdf, when you selected a link for the "Publication" field.
i.e. the very bottom field, named Publication, contains a link to a php page, rather than a pdf asset.
The cryptic error message obviously isn't much help, so I'll amend that.
In the meantime though, the problem should disappear if you select a pdf.
I hope this makes sense.
Kieran

hm.  can we talk about how to handle 'questions' and billing your time? type of thing that I easily could have answered (had I known it existed) and saved you the time (and us the money!)

The solving of this ticket involved improving the message that the user is presented when the wrong type of link is selected, so ... this issue shouldn't happen again (or - at least - it won't incur billable time if it does).

Liz, your point about not necessarily needing this work sounds reasonable to me (even though it's quite useful now it's done!). I am changing this to not billable. In future I am hoping this kind of request can be dealt with via 'capped' billing as mentioned in my email earlier in the week. Let's discuss on Monday.

http://www.london2012.com/fr/games/olympic-sports/
  http://www.london2012.com/fr/games/paralympic/

There are 46 Olympic and Paralympic sports pages linked to from the above pages.
For example, the following:

  http://www.london2012.com/fr/games/paralympic/basket-ball-en-fauteuil-roulant.php
  http://www.london2012.com/fr/games/olympic-sports/athletisme.php
  
Each has a header image at the top of the page.
I'm attaching the two images from the above pages.
The problem is fairly obvious, in that the images have embedded text showing the sport name in English.
In particular, "Wheelchair Basketball" and "Athletics", instead of "Basket-ball en fauteuil roulant" and "Athlétisme".

I believe that Lars requested some new gifs a few weeks ago, but I'm not 100% certain this request was received and/or actioned.

Two simpler alternatives (albeit not particularly desirable) are:
 1. Commission one generic gif for all pages.
 2. Display the English-language gifs (but with French alt-text).

Oh crumbs. I definitely hadn't realised this 'til now. I think we'll need to re-make all those headers...with no words at all in the short term. I'll get on finding the resource to help...

comments.value: We are interested in testing the positioning of elements on the homepage. we would like to create a second version (call it index2) that switches the position of news/blog tabs and the webcams/videos tab.  There is a new feature in google that can direct half of our traffic to the index2 page and the other to our current page, and we can then test the performance of both!  Can you let me know how much work the swap and new page would be?  Do you have any other concerns with the idea?

Hi Liz,

A/B testing !

Sounds like a great idea, will really give you a feel for what is working before you make any lasting changes, in effect free user testing !

And yes, we can certainly get this set-up for you, hopefully without breaking the bank..

We could do this by altering the existing template to render slightly differentially on a random basis and setting the Google analytics tag as appropriate for each version. But this could mean the existing home page template gets cluttered up and bugs introduced, so..

I think my preferred approach (I think the same as what you are suggesting) would be to keep the main home page as the master and then have an alternative versions (that are *never* manually linked to in the CMS or else we could hit issues when we delete the alternatives) each with a different Google tag to mark the variation and then set-up a redirect on the front end of the site to randomly alternate users between the different versions over a period of time. This keeps our existing master template untouched.

So:

- create alternative home page template, with news/video flipped (we could possibly have more than one variation)
- update google analytics code on both versions as appropriate for GA A/B testing
- create an alternative home page indexb.html that is never linked to in the CMS
- setup workflow to repurposes the manually assigned content from the master home page into the alternative version.
- setup workflow to publish the repurposing when the main version is republished.
- setup a redirect on the front end to seamlessly (ie. hidden to the user) deliver alternate versions on a 50/50 (random) basis.
- test / deploy
- remove redirect / alternative template and pages and update master Google tag on main home page after a given period and revert everything back to normal.

I think being realistic that's probably *a day and a half's work* to get it all set up and tested so we are happy to run with it (and also time spent taking it down afterwards) 

Although we'll leave all the redirects and stuff in place / commented out so you can easily run further tests in future (and much more cheaply, basically only our time spent tweaking the alternative version of the template, which I imagine is no more 0.5 day for an small to medium changes).

Lets have a chat if you need clarification on anything..

Jamie

Jamie,

This all sounds excellent! I'm home today (nasty cold/flu thing) but i'll ring you tomorrow and we can discuss - definitely have a few questions ... just want to make sure I understand all the details!

Two things I'd need for that:

1. Some kind of access to google web optimizer. I think they do two flavors, one is (if you've created an experiment already) just a link where I can see the necessary tags I need to add to the page.

2. I don't know how far we're on this - A/B experiments are to compare two or more layouts of the page by measuring how successful are the versions. For this, we need to set up a "goal" and basically measure how many of those goals are reached with each version. The goal is in the case of an e-commerce site would be an order confirmation page (the more goals, the more successful the page). In this case it can be trickier, but would be very useful to find a goal that's fairly general and doesn't change a lot. Jamie mentioned the aim of this specific experiment to increase visits to the webcams (page), is it correct?

Once you start testing your variation pages, WO will measure what proportion of visitors who see each variation go on to reach your conversion page. Right. Could we make an other experiment measuring the news pages as conversions? Yes. Would it be very sensible to compare them with the current results? I think it would be a bit of a moving target. This experiment was to increase the number of visits to the webcams page, and as such it was a half success: there /was/ measurable difference, but it was tiny-tiny. An experience like this should show something like 20% difference between two versions. I'd be overjoyed with 5%.

If, however, as you're suggesting, the aim is to improve the number of -any- clickthroughs (that stay on london2012.com), we could do a completely different experiment saying the conversion is 'user clicks somewhere leaving the homepage and arriving to another page'. This is still not ideal, but we can give it a try.

Danny mentioned there are some KPIs kicking around, and what would be really exciting is to do a testing based on one of those. (Speculation follows:) I suspect there is 'number of new registrations' is on the list. (Oh, what's more, we're measuring the number of registrations and the confirmed registrations as well!) I think there might be some work involved in setting up the funnel properly so you can see where are losing users in the registration process - based on that, we could do some really killer a/b testing to improve the funnel. If you think it might be interesting, I'm happy to detail it in a new story.

The point of changing it to news is to make sure that the 'win' for

From: Paul Deighton 
Sent: 19 March 2010 12:07
To: #LOCOG All Staff Members
Subject: London 2012 appoints Next as sponsor

 

Dear all,

 

I am delighted to inform you that Next have been appointed as Official Clothing and Homeware Supplier to London 2012 and have become our 27th domestic sponsor.

 

The press release with further details is below. 

 

Kind regards

 

Paul

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

19 March 2010

London 2012 appoints Next sponsor

 

- Next becomes London 2012's 27th sponsor

- Will supply clothing to athletes & officials

 

The London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games (LOCOG) has confirmed that Next has been appointed as Official Clothing and Homeware Supplier to London 2012 and has become its 27th domestic sponsor. 

 

Next will design outfits for the opening and closing ceremonies and formal suits for Team GB and Paralympics GB for the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games in 2012. In addition Next will produce formal uniforms for the 4,500 technical officials required for the Games, as well as suits for LOCOG's reception staff. 

 

Next will also supply some of the home furnishings and linen required in the Athletes' Village. 

As part of this partnership with LOCOG, Next will become a LOCOG licensee and Next will use its Creative Team to develop a commercial range of London 2012 clothing and homeware product. 

 

London 2012 Commercial Director Chris Townsend commented, "I'm thrilled that another fantastic British brand has joined us on our journey to 2012. Next is a great brand and I'm confident Next will create a great look for the athletes, officials and staff as well as helping us to make London 2012 product available across the country. We welcome them aboard."

 

Christos Angelides, Executive Director, Next Plc, says "The London 2012 Games is a once in a lifetime opportunity. We are excited at the prospect of working with the BOA, BPA and LOCOG Team. We are all proud of the British athletes and look forward to helping in a small way to make them look great at the Olympic and Paralympic ceremonies. As the official clothing and homeware licensee we look forward to providing our customers with exclusive access to a range of clothing and homeware that reflects the excitement and atmosphere of the London 2012 Olympic Games and Paralympic Games."

 

Next's partnership with London 2012 begins with immediate effect.


- Ends -

 

For further information please contact the London 2012 Press Office on +44 (0)203 2012 100 or visit the website at www.london2012.com. Find out the latest from London 2012 HQ on our blog http://blog.london2012.com  or follow us on Twitter http://www.twitter.com/london2012 

Notes to editors: 

 

As it heads towards its £2bn budget for staging the Olympic and Paralympic Games, LOCOG has seven domestic Tier One Partners - adidas, BMW, BP, British Airways, BT, EDF and Lloyds TSB. There are six domestic Tier Two Supporters - Adecco, Cadbury, Cisco, Deloitte, Thomas Cook and UPS. There are now fourteen domestic Tier Three Suppliers and Providers - Airwave, Atkins, Boston Consulting Group, Crystal CG, Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer LLP, GSK, Holiday Inn, John Lewis, McCann Worldgroup, Next, The Nielsen Company, Populous, Ticketmaster and Trident. 

 

The Worldwide Olympic Partners signed up for London 2012 are Coca-Cola, Acer, Atos Origin, GE, McDonald's, Omega, Panasonic, Samsung and Visa.

Ufff, what a tricky task! 

Yes, the annoying thruth ~ I did put all changes live straight away and the difference it made in the end was hardly anything ( well apart from reducing the HTTP Requests ) . I really tried to squeeze whereever possible (code~wise). Liz please bear in mind that 1000lines of css only equal about 30kb-40kb. ( which is like one of homepage promo images ). So tonight i spent some time with your homepage and we got on tricky in the beginning ~~~

BUT!

I did it! We are now on 0.78mb or 823138kb according to websiteoptimization.com or on 942.8 KB in your favorite webbrowser ( i reckon thats due to javascript preloading of the flash thingies )

I hope those numbers can be confirmed by you or else i have to have another go at it tomorrow.

Lars
